[Using 1 late day]

Sorry I didn't really get to finish this project.
I got my second COVID vaccine shot, and was crawling for the past 10 days.

I couldn't understand how the EM step should be implemented.
But I really do want to make this a learning opportunity.

So at first we begin with a WMM of size (S x 13), but to evaluate this WMM, we need to run it through all sequences.
I get a (S x String length - motif length + 1) sized evaluation, but couldn't understand how to move on from here.

I needed to construct a new WMM with weights, but I understand that the weights can vary from position to position?
I was really stuck from here and on and couldn't finish the entire thing.

If I could get a feedback on how the EM step should be implemented on code, it would be really helpful.

------------------------------------------- Questions -------------------------------------------

Q1.
Mean = 0
Variance = 11
Standard Deviation = 3.31

Q2.
Mean = 0
Variance = 50/n (so higher n is lower variance)
Standard Deviation = sqrt 50/n (so higher n is lower standard deviation)

Q3.
From what I know, we are attempting a brute force approach.
There will be (a lot) of "bad" predictions, but that is simply due to the method we are approaching with.
If we approached this with "Greedy Best-First" method, we would have much less "bad" predictions,
but the final prediction won't be as accurate.

Q4.
We can get really close to the actual start position, but there will be some fluctuation.
From Q2, we can see that the variance will get lower and lower, but never reach 0.
This is true with even the biggest sample size, so accounting for that fluctuation,
we can get really close to the actual start position, but can't be certain of it.

Q5.
My WMMD and WMME tables are... bad, so I'll just make another guess here.
I gave my explanation of why the starting positions can be off on Q4.
To explain a bit more, we are running 10 instances of EM, which might not be enough to land us on the right spot.
We can increase the number of iterations, which will increase the likelihood, but never can be certain we
landed on the exact spot.
